David,

Not disagreeing with Curran at all, as I am a cautious
preservation=
ist. "Do no harm" is my motto, and from the photos though
it looks like the=
 lacquer doesn't add to the appeal, I would be
worrying what the patina wil=
l look like in those areas if you do
remove it. If it ends up blotchy, you =
would have to look at
repatinating the whole piece, leaving it hardly origi=
nal.

Of course the argument can be reasonably made that the lacquer (or
pa=
int, Milt) - being a later add-on - makes it impossible to have the
"origin=
al" article without some restoration. While there are those who
believe tha=
t all tsuba as we have them today have been messed with and
should be taken=
 down to bare metal and patinated "as originally
intended," they are in the=
 minority, and I would question their claim
to certain knowledge of what wa=
s "originally intended" by the artisan.

Wait a few weeks, David, you will =
get a number of more qualified
opinions in person at the San Francisco Toke=
n Kai.

Craig


-- 
Craig Harris
Books from and about Asia
www.bridgeofdrea=
ms.com

On 7/16/05, Curran Campbell <neobliviscar@...> wrote:
> David=
,
> 
> I would say yours is later than the ko-umetada. I
> don't know how m=
uch later. I'm just basing my opinion
> off the seppa dai and some of the o=
ther measurements.
> Maybe yours is 50 to 100 years younger than the
> ko-u=
metada photographed. My confidence level isn't
> super high though, so don'=
t quote me. Just sticking my
> neck out to risk an opinion.
> 
> As to the =
black lacquer- thats your call. If the
> lacquer is fair to good quality, I=
 personally would be
> inclined to leave it. I'm of the minimally invasive
=
> school of thought. Clean it to a preservation point of
> view.
>    If th=
e lacquer is well done and has survived this
> long, I consider it part of =
the atmosphere of the
> piece. If its a hack job, boil away.
> 
> Curran
> =

> 
> 
>

n almost identical tsuba (evidently without
